{"step_by_step_thinking": "In this study, the researchers retrospectively surveyed mothers with children diagnosed with ASD and mothers with healthy children. They interviewed the participants about their prenatal consumption of folic acid using standardized questionnaires. The key point to note is that the study relied on the participants' ability to accurately recall their folic acid supplementation before pregnancy. Recall bias refers to the systematic error that occurs when participants have difficulty accurately recalling past events or exposures. In this case, the mothers may have overestimated or underestimated their folic acid supplementation, leading to biased results. Therefore, the most likely type of bias that influenced these results is recall bias.", "answer_choice": "C. Recall bias"}
